description: Big Bang singularity

ignition ofhydrogen stars, bathing the Universe in first light ofcosmic dawn→ helium in stars fusing into carbon, leading tostellar nucleosynthesisof all elements; earliestgalaxiesandblack holesforming 290 million and 400 million years after the Big Bang
aggregation of stars into theMilky Waygalaxy
earliestwater
formation of theSunandSolar Systemwithin the Milky Way, orbiting a supermassive black hole,SagittariusA*, at itsGalacticCentreevery 220 million years
formation of theMoonfrom amassive impactof protoplanetTheiawith proto-Earth, during chaoticinstabilityof the giant planets
formation of planetEarthwith 510 million km² of surface area, orbiting the Sun on a yearly cycle, rotating eastward on a day-night cycle around a tilted axis that perpetuates opposing polar seasons
formation of Earth’soceansandmoistatmosphere, protected from solar wind and cosmic rays by Earth’smagnetospheregenerated by itsiron core
earliestsubductionof Earth’s crust → continentalplate tectonicsby at least3.5 billion years ago, unique to Earth in the Solar System; plateboundariesshiftingcontinuously
basaltic rock glass catalyses formation of RNA (HadeanEon)
earliest life on Earth
photosynthesising bacteria amongst the Archaea (ArcheanEon), converting sunlight into chemical energy to power cellular activity →cyanobacteriathemost abundantof all organisms ever existing on Earth
earliest atmospheric oxygen, present at low levels (ArcheanEon)
a gigantic meteorite strikes Earth (ArcheanEon),triggering a global tsunami, boiling the world’s ocean, lowering sea level, darkening the sky, churning up nutrients for iron-cycling microbes
emergence of Earth’s first continents from the ocean (ArcheanEon, 3.3 to 3.2 billion years ago), supporting microbial mats in Earth’s firstland ecosystem
the Great Oxygenation Event

early multicellular life, with cell-to-cell signalling and coordinated responses (ProterozoicEon) → the human body containing28-36trillion cells inhundredsof mutually-dependenttypes, plus a similar order of commensalmicrobeswithout whichwe die
earliest Eukaryotes amongst the Prokaryotes (ProterozoicEon),arising from the merger of anarchaeonwith a bacterium
giant viruses associating with red algae (ProterozoicEon)
earliest fungi amongst the Eukaryotes (ProterozoicEon)
earliest Metazoa – animals – amongst the Eukaryotes
massive volcanism and outgassing triggersSnowball Earthglaciation lasting56 million years
Neoproterozoic Oxygenation Event
earliest stem Cnidaria amongst the animals (earlyEdiacaranPeriod),ancestor ofjellyfishand immortalhydra
earliest bilaterian animals, with left-right symmetry (EdiacaranPeriod)
explosion in animal diversification over 20 million years (earliestCambrianPeriod);emergence of modern body plans, resolving tophylaover 40 million years
earliest chordates amongst the bilaterians (Early CambrianPeriod)
ancestral vertebrates amongst the chordates (CambrianPeriod), with stomach, gill arches, camera-type eyes, andolfactory organ
earliest acute visual perception
first colonisation of land by plants
earliest excursions onto land by animals (Middle CambrianPeriod)
radiation of vertebrates (Early OrdovicianPeriod), possibly facilitated bygenome duplication
earliest insects amongst the arthropods (Early OrdovicianPeriod) → flight by 406 million years ago; modern insects exhibiting capacity forsubjective experience, a marker for consciousness
earliest vertebrate skeletons with living bone
mass extinction in two pulses across 1 million years, eliminating more than three-quarters of all species (Late OrdovicianPeriod),linked to volcanic activity
evolution of paired nostrils amongst the fishes (SilurianPeriod), aprerequisiteto the development of jaws → human nosedetectingmore than1 trillion odours,categorisedby associatedmemories
earliest jawed vertebrates amongst the fishes (Late SilurianPeriod) → diversification of feeding niches; capacity foryawningandempathy, omnipresent across disparate modern lineages;synovial joints
earliest acoustic communication, by aquatic vertebrates (Early DevonianPeriod)
earliest woody stems of vascular plants (Early DevonianPeriod, France, Gondwana)→ evolution driven by hydraulic constraints, pre-adapting plants for taller morphologies
earliest tetrapods amongst the vertebrates (DevonianPeriod, Poland, Euramerican shallow marine lagoons)
earliest forests (DevonianPeriod, Britain, Euramerica)→ three-dimensional terrestrial habitat, trees connected bymycorrhizal fungi; risingatmospheric O₂and diminishing CO₂
earliest vertebrate multi-chambered heart (placoderm fish,DevonianPeriod, Australia, Gondwanan onshore reefs)→ the human heartbeat ahearty,heartlessorheartfeltrhythm,brokenby emotional trauma
mass extinction in a series of pulses across 20 million years, eliminating more than two-thirds of all species (Late DevonianPeriod),linked to climatic cooling
earliest land vertebrates (Early CarboniferousPeriod, Britain, Euramerica)
earliest fully terrestrial tetrapod vertebrates, laying amniote eggs (CarboniferousPeriod, Britain, Euramerica)
earliest evidence of parental care of offspring by a tetrapod

Earth’s largest mass extinction, eliminating four-fifths of all species during 61,000 years (Permian-Triassictransition),caused by hot and acidifying CO₂ emissions from vocanic Siberian Traps,amplified bymega-El Niños→ rapid bioticrecovery
dawn of the modern world
earliest warm-blooded stem mammals (Late Triassic)

mass extinction event, eliminating more than two-thirds of all species (Triassic-Jurassictransition), linked tovolcanic CO₂from the Central Atlantic Magmatic Province,equivalent to projections forCE21ˢᵗ century anthropogenic emissions
earliest true mammals amongst the terrestrial vertebrates (JurassicPeriod)
evolutionary transition to birds from therapod dinosaurs (Late Jurassic)
major radiations of floweringplantsand their insect pollinators in theEarly CretaceousPeriod
aerobic bacteria embed into oxic sediment of the South Pacific Gyre(Cretaceous Period),reviving after101.5 million yearsto grow into microbial communities

earliest mammal louse (CretaceousPeriod)→ body-, pubic- and head-lice, bedbugs, screwworms and botflies, fleas, ticks, scabies and chiggers amongst theectoparasitesof modern humans, with 300 worm and 70 protozoanendoparasites

abrupt mass extinction of non-avian dinosaurs, with three-quarters of all species, following thespringtimeimpact of a10-kmwideasteroidatChicxulub, Mexico(Cretaceous-Paleogenetransition)→ rapid diversification offlowering plantsandmammals
radiation of placental mammals (post-Cretaceous-Paleogeneboundary)
earliest primates amongst the mammals (EoceneEpoch)
divergence of Old World from New World primates (EoceneEpoch)
freezing over ofAntarctica,henceforth shrouding the continental landmass in ice
a virus embeds its DNA into a primate’s genome, evolving into anendogenous retrovirus→ active in modern humans
earliest hominoids (apes) amongst the Old World primates (Tanzania, Oligocene Epoch)
earliest hominids (great apes) amongst the hominoid gibbons inAsia
hominidsPierolapithecus catalaunicusinSpain,andNyanzapithecus alesiinKenya,possible ancestors ofhomininsand modern apes respectively, the former withupright posture; capacity forplayful teasing
earliest homininSahelanthropus, thenOrrorinandArdipithecus, amongst the hominids inAfrica
replacement of the earliest hominins byAustralopithecusspp. inAfrica
earliest knapped stone artefacts
earliest human,Homosp., amongst the hominins (Ledi-Geraru, Ethiopia)
range expansion of hominin genusParanthropus(East Africa),co-existingwith humans
incorporation of meat and marrow intogeneralistdiets of hominins (Africa); hunting by ambush, stalking, andendurance pursuitof prey?
earliest stone tools produced by humans (Gona, Ethiopia)
start of the current geological period ofQuaternaryglaciation, possibly initiated by asupernova blast150-300 light-years away, luminous as the full Moon
Homo habilisinAfrica, using stone tools for cleaving meat from bone
earliest evidence of human ancestors outside of Africa
earlyHomo erectus, direct ancestor of modern humans, coexisting withAustralopithecus– soon extinct, andParanthropus(South Africa)

migrations ofHomo erectusfromAfricatoEurasia(Georgia;toLantianin northern Chinaby 1.63 million years ago; toJavaby 1.5 million years ago?); ecological success underwritten bypostmenopausalcare of young?
earliest evidence of extended childhood (11-year oldHomo,Dmanisi, Georgia),characteristic ofmodern humans, linked to slow development of baby teeth
earliest stone hand axes (Olduvai Gorge, Tanzania)
earliest control of fire, byHomo erectus(Koobi Fora, Kenya)
male-male alliances inHomo erectussocial groups (Ileret, Kenya)
hominins butchering and consuming other hominins (Koobi Fora, Kenya)
earliest organic tools
replacement ofHomo habilisbyHomo erectusinAfrica, also dispersing into easternEuropeand spreading west, establishing in Europe at least by900,000 years ago
extinction ofParanthropus(South Africa), our last remaining sibling genus
ancestral humans undergo the first of a series of bifurcations into weakly differentiated populations connected by gene flow (pan-Africa) → no singlebirthplaceof modern humans

population bottleneck for the ancestors of modern humans inAfrica, reducing fromc. 100,000 to 1,300 individuals, persisting forc. 100,000 years during drastic climate change →diasporafrom Africa to Europe
Homo antecessorin western Europe (Gran Dolina,Spain), closely related to the last common ancestor of Neanderthals, Denisovans and modern humans
flint scrapers associated withHomo antecessor(Gran Dolina,Spain), suitable for preparing animal hides → clothing?
earliest cannibalism, inHomo antecessor(Gran Dolina, Spain), practised throughout human history;socialmotivation?
rise ofHomo heidelbergensisinAfricaandEurope, possible ancestor ofHomo sapiensandHomo neanderthalensis; supplementing meat withstarchy plants
diminutiveHomo floresiensison the Indonesian island ofFlores,probabledescendentofHomo erectus
earliest abstract markings
earliest use of stone-tipped spears, byHomo heidelbergensis(Kathu Pan, South Africa)for hunting large game
earliest wooden construction (Kalambo Falls, Zambia), of interlocking logs joined by a cut notch
rise of NeanderthalsHomo neanderthalensisacrossEurope
Denisovans diverge from Neanderthals (southern Siberia) →Tibetan PlateauandLaosby 160,000 years ago;subsequentinterbreeding, possibly also withHomo erectus
multiple hominin dispersals across Arabia (Nefud Desert), during windows of desert greening at four-, three-, two- and one-hundred thousand years ago
earliest evidence of food storage for later consumption
long-distance transport of obsidian for fine blades and points, andochrefor pigments (Olorgesailie, Kenyan rift valley)
earliest evidence of our species,Homo sapiens(Jebel Irhoud, Morocco)
wood age ofHomo heidelbergensisandH. neanderthalensis(Schöningen,Germany)
replacement ofHomo heidelbergensisbyHomo neanderthalensisinEurope, and byHomo sapiensinAfricaover the subsequent 100,000 years
earliest anatomically modernHomo sapiens, in eastern Africa (Omo-Kibish, Ethiopia)
Homo sapiensenterEurasia(Greece)
compassion among Neanderthals (Cova Negra, Spain)
recurrent interbreeding ofHomo sapienswithHomo neanderthalensis(Eurasiaand subsequentlySiberia) → accumulation of modern traits through gene flow
earliest adhesive
earliest social construction
widespread use of clothing, setting humans apart from all other animals, evidenced in the divergence of clothing lice from head lice (Africa)
coastal shellfish harvested byHomo sapiensinsouthern Africa,and by Neanderthals in thewestern Mediterranean→ fatty acids boosting cognitive development
earliest symbolic ornaments
Homowith mix of archaic-human and Neanderthal traits (Nesher Ramla,Israel)
prelude to Earth’s Last Glacial Period
Neanderthals living and working in large groups (northernEuropeanplain), evidenced by butchered 13-tonne elephants, each provisioning 100 people for a month
burial of dead, by anatomically modern humans inQafzeh Cave, Israel,and by Neanderthals inTabun Cave, Israel
last appearance ofHomo erectus(Ngandong, Java), 1.89 million years after its first appearance → the longest enduring species of human
hoarding of non-utilitarian objects byHomo sapiens
possible first arrival ofHomo sapiensinEast Asia,attracted to verdant landscapes produced by strengthening monsoons
toolkit for mixing and storing pigments
earliest human etchings on rock
manufacture of bone harpoons, for hunting catfish (Semliki river, DR Congo)
fisher-hunter-gatherer Neanderthals eating mussels, crab, eels, sea bream and shark, dolphins and seals, hoofed game and waterfowl; pine-nut economy (Figueira Brava, Portugal)
earliest symbolic human burial, a 3-year oldHomo sapiens(Panga ya Saidi Cave, Kenya)
construction of bedding from sedges, topped with aromatic leaves containing insecticidal and larvicidal chemicals (Sibudurock shelter, South Africa)
early modernHomo sapienspresent in southeast Asia (Tam Pà Ling Cave, Laos), possibly migrating through as early as86,000 years ago, settling at least by 68,000 years ago
earliest jewellery fashions
earliest drawing by humans
earliest heat-treatment of bladelets, for atlatl darts or arrows (Pinnacle Point, South Africa)
cooking of crushed pulse seeds by Neanderthals (Shanidar Cave, Iraqi Kurdistan)
rapid colonisation of Australia by humans during5,000 years(ancientSahul)
earliest symbolic cave paintings by Neanderthals (La Pasiega Cave, Spain)?
bow-and-arrow technology, with bone arrowhead (Sibudu rock shelter, South Africa); a sprung bow the first instrument to hold energy for controlled release
earliest number symbols
symbolic burial of dead by Neanderthals(La Chapelle-aux-Saints, France)
beginning of range expansion by modern humans out of Africa intoEurasia, enduring 10,000 years →ancestorsof all modern non-Africans; onset of behavioural modernity
modern humans,Homo sapiens, settling briefly in western Europe (Grotte Mandrin, France)?– preceded by and preceding Neanderthal settlements
earliest representational art
a giant deer’s phalanx bone becomes a Neanderthal artist’s canvas, prepared by scraping and boiling before etching (Harz Mountains, Germany)
earliest use of string
earliest eyed needle, made from bone by Denisovans (Denisova Cave, Siberia), suitable for tailoring garments
Neanderthal fire-lighting technology (France)
EurasianHomo sapiensco-existing withHomo floresiensis(soon extinct) andHomo luzonensis, interbreeding withNeanderthalsandDenisovans
a giant virus freezes into permafrost ofYukechialas, Siberia,melting back to virulent activity 48,500 years later →pandemic risk
self-medication by Neanderthals, with pain-killing salicylic acid in poplar leaves, and antibiotic-producingPenicilliummould (El Sidrón, Spain)
anatomically modern humans, Homo sapiens,established inEurope(Bacho Kiro,Bulgaria;Ilsenhöhle,Germany),matingwith Neanderthals, spreading eastwards.
complex processing of food plants by anatomically modern humans (Niah Cave, Borneo)
extinction of giant flightless mihirung thunder birds, hastened by human exploitation of their eggs (Australia)
figurative painting of therianthropes hunting anoa and pigs (Leang Bulu’ Sipong 4, Sulawesi)
earliest musical instruments
earliest record of fish-hooks, manufactured from broken shell (Jerimalai shelter, East Timor)
most recent reversal of Earth’s magnetic poles, lasting500 years, degrading stratospheric ozone, driving global climate shifts and extinction events
anatomically modern humansreplaceNeanderthals, our last remaining sibling species
full development oflanguage;personal namesfacilitating efficient social bonding throughgossip→ now over7,000living languages, over2,000vanishing
earliest habitual footwear (Tianyuan, China), opening permafrost regions to occupancy; widespread across Russiaby 27,000 years ago → hay socks by5,000 years ago
earliest figurative sculpture, in ivory, of a therianthrope with lion’s head and human torso (Hohlenstein-Stadel, Germany)
earliest images of human form
earliest artistic representation of human form
earliest animation in cave art (Grotte Chauvet-Pont d’Arc,France)
earliest fully human sculpture and female imagery
cultural identity exhibited in personal ornaments fashioned from stone, shell, ivory, bone, and teeth from humans and animals (Gravettian technocomplex, pan-European)
processing of heat-dried wild oats with grindstones (Grotta Paglicci, Italy;soon appearing acrossEurope,Australia), to make flour for storage and cooking
fruits of the campionSilene stenophyllafreeze inSiberiantundra,regenerating from cryobiosis 32,000 years later into fertile plants
possible first human incursions into the Americas (Mexico), certainly within the next 11,000 years (NewMexico), migrating along the coast fromSiberia?
earliest surgical amputation, of a child’s lower leg (Liang Tebo, Borneo);the amputee surviving for 6 to 9 years, then burial
earliest woven fabrics, made from dyed fibres of wild flax (Georgia)→ baskets, textile clothing
earliest stone statuette
possible first human incursions into South America (Santa Elina, Brazil);colonisingPeruby 15,000 years ago; humans henceforth occupying every continent except Antarctica
a coronavirus epidemic sweeps throughEast Asia, driving genetic adaptations still present in modern humans
use of poison arrows, with wooden ricin applicator (Lebombo mountains, South Africa)
a bdelloid rotifer freezes into ice in the Alayeza river (Russian Arctic), reviving 24,000 years later to full vigour
fisher-hunter-gatherer brush huts (Sea of Galilee, Levant)
earliest fishing-net sinkers (Sea of Galilee, Levant) → modern industrial fishing currently in 55% of ocean area, covering4×agricultural area
first domestication
earliest pottery vessels (Xianrendong Cave, China)
beginning of sea-level rise fromdeglaciationin a warming global climate; stabilising at today’s 120-m higher levels byc. 10,000 years ago
replacement of early modern humans acrossEurasiaby the ancestors of today’s populations
a quaking aspen sapling grows into a tree amongst other clones of the same root system, some perhaps 64,000 years older, spreading across 40 ha over the next 16,000 years (Utah, North America)
introgression of last remainingDenisovansinto the modern human genome? Anatomically modern humans henceforth the only hominin
colonisation and occupation of North America by humans, from northeasternSiberiaover theBeringland bridge, bringing theirdogs
semi-permanent forager settlements of Natufians (Ain Mallaha, Levant), evidenced by presence of house mice
earliest record of a string instrument
earliest thaumatrope (Laugerie-Basserock shelter, France)
evidence of baking bread
earliest lime plaster, used as an adhesive for hafting (Kebaran culture, North Sinai)→ mortar by 1000BCE
earliest evidence of large-scale inter-communal violence
earliest record of ritual torture, by strangulation (Addaura Caveengravings, Sicily)
earliest record of artistic expression through dance, as rite of passage (engravings inSicily;paintings inIndia)
climate shift contributing to megafaunal extinctions and human cultural changes (Younger Dryas)
earliest evidence of humans using tobacco (West Desert, North America)
domestication ofCannabis(East Asia) → breeding for hemp-type and drug-type varieties byc. 1800BCE
oldest record of a culturally transmitted ritual practice (CloggsCave, Australia)
extinction of megafauna including woolly mammoths from continentalEurasiaandNorth America, caused by human hunting and climate change
start of theHolocene Epochwithin the Quaternary Period, characterised by warm and stable climate until the lateCE20ᵗʰ century
in the North American Mojave desert,a seed germinates and grows into adeadlycreosote bush, which segments to sprout new stems, sprouting and segmenting for11,700 years
earliest monumental ritual art (Shigir, Siberia)

full development oflanguage;personal namesfacilitating efficient social bonding throughgossip→ now over7,000living languages, over2,000vanishing

understanding that wisdom stems from knowing what we don’t know (attributed to Socrates, ancient Greece, in Plato’sApology) → beauty infreedomfrom the known

counterfactual thinking (Thucydides’History of the Peloponnesian War, ancient Greece), encompassing regrets and relief about unfulfilledpossibilities

idea that justice and virtue are inherent qualities of inner harmony (Plato’sRepublic, ancient Greece)

concept of time-velocity space (Babylonia)
development of formal systems of reasoning, by logical deduction from axioms and postulates (Aristotle’sMetaphysics, ancient Greece) → scientific disciplines

understanding of comedy as an absurdity exposed (Aristotle’sPoetics,ancient Greece)

mass persuasion, using silver coins stamped with the head of previous legendary ruler Alexander the Great (Lampsacus, Anatolia)

postulation of Euclidean geometry of flat surfaces (Euclid of Alexandria, ancient Greece) → first printed edition of Euclid’sElements,CE1482

fusion of Indian cultures and traditions intoHinduism, with worship posthumously rewarded by favourable rebirth; torment in hell for sinners → currently the third most populous religion,afterChristianity and Islam
widespread adoption of seed drills (Han dynasty,northern China); reinvention by Jethro Tull inCE1701, Britain → production efficiency heralding the dawn of modern agriculture
